posts.name: Joshua Truman
posts.cooked: During a competition, our WAGO terminal for battery wire shorted and melted (see [this post](https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/pdh-input-hub-wire-melted/460585)). After taking it apart, we discovered it was soldered on, making it non-replaceable. Should we consider alternative solutions to salvage the PDH even if it cannot be utilized in a competition setting?

posts.name: Roger Moore
posts.cooked: REV Robotics offers a repair service for their Power Distribution Hubs. These hubs are designed for educational purposes, including use in competitions such as FIRST Robotics. The repair service is priced at USD 110, and interested individuals can contact REV support for more information.

link_counts.title: Power Distribution Hub Repair Service - REV Robotics

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked: Wagon terminals used in PDPs are made by WAGO to be soldered on. I believe you can purchase new terminals from Digi-Key, though I'm uncertain about their compliance with competition regulations due to the significant power running through these ports.

posts.name: Marcus Kauffman
posts.cooked: The same team as @jt4929 based on the photos he sent me, it appears the wago has melted rather than the wire insulation. Two images were included in the analysis: one with dimensions 944Ã—1071 pixels (165 KB) and another larger version measuring 750Ã—1000 pixels (2x resolution). Another image was added showing 1536Ã—2048 pixels (445 KB). Looks like it could be a different issue than the one from the linked post.

If you want to repair it yourselfâ€”the connector used is WAGO 2616-1352. You could obtain this somewhere else, though it isnâ€™t currently in stock at DigiKey. Desolder the existing connections and replace them with this one. Be cautious since it doesnâ€™t have the typical red and black colors. According to the game manual, this modification is permitted under R710: Only specified modifications to control system devices are permitted. The Driver Station Software, roboRIO, PDH, PCM(s)/PH(s), VRM/RPM(s), RSL, 120A breaker, motor controllers, MXP devices, relay modules, wireless bridge, PDH/PDP2.0/PDH breakers and fuses, Servo Power Module, Servo Hub, Kraken Powerpole adapter boards, and batteries shall not be tampered with, modified, or adjusted in any way (tampering includes drilling, cutting, machining, rewiring, disassembling, painting, etc.), with the exception of replacing control system power terminal blocks (e.g., RSL power connectors) with functional equivalents. Devices may be repaired, provided the performance and specifications after repair match those before. However, I couldnâ€™t see an inspector passing this, and I definitely wouldnâ€™t recommend this over REVâ€™s Repair Service. EDIT: It seems to be in stock at [link].

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked: Itâ€™s also probably going to take a lot of heat to desolder. A small section of conductor lies on both rails.

posts.name: Clayton Yocom
posts.cooked: Weâ€™ve repaired one of ours this way (and set aside to be used on practice chassis/demo robots), be warned it does take a beefy soldering iron to handle this amount of copper.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
Hereâ€™s the cleaned-up version based on your instructions:

A high-power soldering iron will be necessary, as others have stated. If you donâ€™t have a good level of experience reworking circuit boards, itâ€™s actually quite easy to permanently damage the circuit board.
